syllabus:
**Testimonial Literature and the Question of Ethics and Aesthetics**

**Fall 2020**

Instructor: Jessie Shao 邵毓娟                                        Email: ycshao@ntnu.edu.tw

Office: Cheng 808                                                              Tel: 77491786

**I. Goals:**

The ethical turn, which has become a predominant mode of thinking since the 1980s, has prompted the academics to confront the questions of trauma and collective responsibility left behind as a result of violent histories such as the Holocaust, slavery, colonialism, and other events of violence. Yet over the past decade, the tendency of such ethical intervention has triggered concern and reflections over the ways the desire to claim moral and political potency may lead to critical impasse in many ethical discussions. This course aims to explore this contested field through the study of contemporary testimonial literature and cultural and philosophical accounts with regard to ethics, aesthetics, and politics. As a means of articulation, a way of intervention, and also an ethical gesture, in what ways aesthetic expression may bring about its own ethical imaginary and approach so as to resist “the tendency of simplification and the intellectual and moral limitations caused by such simplification,” as Primo Levi points out in his essay “The Gray Zone”? This, I think, is the main concern of this course.

**II. Tentative Syllabus:**

**Week 1: Orientation**

Focus Topic: The Ethical Turn of Aesthetics and Politics

Discussion material: “The Ethical Turn of Aesthetics and Politics” by Jacques Rancière (from _Dissensus_)

**Week 2:**

Focus Topic: The Encounter between Ethics and Aesthetics

Reading materials: “What Aesthetics Means” by Jacques Rancière; “Chapter 1 Education and Crisis” by Shoshanna Felman” (from _Testimony: Cries of Witnessing in Literature, Psychoanalysis, and History_); “What We Talk about When We Talk about Ethics” by Lawrence Buell (from _The Turn to Ethics_)

**Week 3:**

Focus Topic: Primo Levi and the Gray Zone: Reflections on the Legacy of Holocaust Studies

Reading materials: “The Memory of the Offense,” “The Gray Zone,” “Shame” from _The Drowned and the Saved_ by Primo Levi

**Week 4:**

Focus Topic: Primo Levi and the Testimonial Writing

Reading materials: “The Intellectual in Auschwitz” from _The Drowned and the Saved_ by Primo Levi; “Time and Identity,” “The Language of Memorial in the Testimonial Writing of Primo Levi” by Judith Kelly (from _Primo Levi: Recording and Reconstruction in the Testimonial Literature_)

**Week 5:**

Focus Topic: The Politics of Aesthetics

Reading materials: “What Freud Has to Do with Aesthetics,” and “The Two Forms of Mute Speech” (_The Aesthetic Unconscious_ by Jacques Rancière);  “The Distribution of the Sensible: Politics and Aesthetics,” and “The Politics of Literature” (_Dissensus_ by Jacques Rancière)

**Week 6:**

Focus Topic: “Performing the Void?”—Toward a Critical Approach to Testimonial Literature

Reading materials: Excerpts from _The Stolen Bicycle_ by Wu Ming-yi; “Who Has the Right to Feel? The Ethics of Literary Empathy” by Kathleen Lundeen (from _Mapping the Ethical Turn_ eds. by Todd F. Davis and Kenneth Womack); “On Cultural Choice” by Homi Bhabha (from _The Turn_ _to Ethics_ eds. by Marjorie Garber et al.)

**Week 7:**

Focus Topic: “Performing the Void?”—Toward a Critical Approach to Testimonial Literature

Reading materials: Part III of _The Narrow Road to the Deep North_ by Richard Flanagan (pp. 159-270); “Performing the Void: Liminality and the Ethics of Form in Contemporary Trauma Narratives” by Jean-Michel Ganteau and Susaba Onega

**Week 8:**

Focus Topic: Testimonial Literature and Contested Pasts

Reading materials: Part IV of _The Narrow Road to the Deep North_ by Richard Flanagan (pp. 159-270); “A Humanistic Ethics of Reading” by Daniel R. Schwarz (from _Mapping the Ethical Turn_ eds. by Todd F. Davis and Kenneth Womack)

**Week 9:**

Focus Topic: Thinking Critically toward the Reconstruction of Memory

Reading materials: “The Generation of Postmemory,” “Surviving Images” from _The Generation of Postmemory: Writing and Visual Culture after the Holocaust_ by Marianne Hirsch

**Week 10:**

Focus Topic: The Legacy of the Holocaust

Reading materials: “At the Limits of Eurocentrism: Hannah Arendt’s _The Origins of Totalitarianism_” (from _Multidirectional Memory: Remembering the Holocaust in the Age of Decolonization_ by Michael Rothberg); “Haunting Legacies: Trauma in Children of Perpetrators” (_Haunting Legacies: Violent Histories and Transgenerational Trauma_ by Gabriele Schwab)

**Week 11:**

Focus Topic: Ethical Ambivalence

“Social Bonds and Psychical Order: Testimonies” by Susannah Radstone; “Ethical Ambivalence” by Judith Butler (from _The Turn_ _to Ethics_ eds. by Marjorie Garber et al.); “Exactly and Responsibly: A Defense of Ethical Criticism” by Martha C. Nussbaum (from _Mapping the Ethical Turn_ eds. by Todd F. Davis and Kenneth Womack)

**Week 12:**

Focus Topic: Implication, Ethics, and Politics

Reading materials: Chapters 1-13 of _Disgrace_ by J. M. Coetzee; “Afterlives: In the Wake of the TRC” by Gillian Whitlock (from _Postcolonial Life Narratives: Testimonial Transaction_); “Introduction: From Victims and Perpetrators to Implicated Subjects” (from _The Implicated Subject: Beyond Victims and Perpetrators_ by Michael Rothberg)

**Week 13:**

Focus Topic: Implication, Ethics, and Politics

Reading materials: Chapters 14-24 of _Disgrace_ by J. M. Coetzee; “Ethics before Politics: J. M. Coetzee’s _Disgrace_” by James Meffan and Kim L. Worthington (from _Mapping the Ethical Turn_ eds. by Todd F. Davis and Kenneth Womack)

**Week 14:**

Focus Topic: Trauma Narratives and Liminality

Reading materials: “Identity Trouble: Guilt, Shame, and Idealization” (_Haunting Legacies: Violent Histories and Transgenerational Trauma_ by Gabriele Schwab); “Sethe’s Choice: _Beloved_ and the Ethics of Reading” by James Phelan (from _Mapping the Ethical Turn_ eds. by Todd F. Davis and Kenneth Womack)

**Week 15:**

Focus Topic: Testimonial Literature and Truth

Reading materials: Excerpts from _The One Man’s Bible_ by Gao Xingjian; “Lyrical Ethics and Literary Experience” by Charles Altieri (from _Mapping the Ethical Turn_ eds. by Todd F. Davis and Kenneth Womack)

**Week 16:**

Focus Topic: Moralism and Its Ethical Problems

Reading materials: Excerpts from _Do Not Say We Have Nothing_ by Madeleine Thien; “Moral Repair and Its Limits” by Margaret Urban Walker (from _Mapping the Ethical Turn_ eds. by Todd F. Davis and Kenneth Womack)

**Week 17:**

Focus Topic: Ethics and Testimonial Culture (Term Paper Plan)

Reading material: “Making, Taking, and Faking Lives: Ethical Problems in Collaborative Life Writing” by G. Thomas Couser

**Week 18: Term Paper Due**

**III. Requirements:**

1.  Oral Presentations
2.  Term Paper

**IV****.** **Grading Policy:** Your grade will be given based on your performance on the following aspects: 1. Attendance and participation 25%; 2. Oral Presentations 25%; 3. Term Paper 50%.
